title: Can an opposing attorney file a joint pretrial stipulation without conferring with me?
question: I am representing myself in a my bankruptcy adversary case because that is all I can afford at the present time. I realize it's an uphill battle. I also expect some abuse by the attorney representing the plaintiff. Here is my current situation: The plaintiff's attorney filed a joint pretrial stipulation without ever consulting with me. They sent me an email asking me to call, which I did. I spoke to the attorney and she stated we could do this through a series of email exchanges until we reached something that both of us could agree on. She was in somewhat of a hurry to get this done because the document was due the next day. That never happened. It begins as follows: "Subject to the approval of the above names court, all parties submit the following Pretrial Stipulation:..." The rest of the document is completely one sided with absolutely nothing that I agree with. My opinion, evidence, etc.. was nowhere to be found. It was filed an entered by the court on May 13. I just received the document yesterday. Is this legal what the attorney did? What can I do? Thank you.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 13 bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Chapter 13 bankruptcy reorganization plan
answers: Good advice has been provided by my colleagues. Filing a unilateral report is the best option for you right now. Be sure to monitor the case for any hearings that might be scheduled and make sure you "appear" at the hearing. I understand the issue with lack of funds to hire an attorney, but representing yourself in an adversary proceeding is not easy. Perhaps you can locate a bankruptcy attorney in your area that will provide some guidance for a reasonable fee.

Yes, they can, should they without true joint agreements, no. You do not say whether any of what is agreeable is in it, and so if it is nothing you agreed to or would agree to then file a declaration stating you did not agree. Be ready to explain why you could not meet and confer and state you do not agree at the hearing. Again, not everything needed to answer this question was stated in your question. Tell the court BEFORE the hearing that you did not jointly file. Then at the hearing explain why you didn't meet and confer and agree to the stipulation and ask them to not approve.

All the above are correct. You should file a unilateral one if your position was not included in the joint one. You can provide the introduction of why you're filing it individually because the joint one was filed without your information.

As since you received their status report, you can use that as a template of information you are suppose to provide. Not a time for arguing against their points, but you to assert your position and points for each categorized item that's on the status report. (This way the judge can see where disputes and disagreements are).

However, judges and local rules provide for the exact categories of information that you are supposed to include in a status report and it is best to look up your judge's rules and local rules always.

Joint pre-trial statement is required. If, after efforts to secure joint pre-trial statement are not successful, either or both party(s) may file unilateral pre-trial status report.
Failure to file pre-trial status report places you at significant disadvantage.
Not a DIY project. You are lost. You need to hire an attorney to get on the litigation train or suffer consequences.

Yes, a status report stating Plaintiff's position is allowed. You can file your own status report, if you would like to. Ultimately the Judge will not make a ruling based the status report filed by Plaintiff's counsel. The Judge will hear your side of things as well.
You can file your unilateral status report seven days before the hearing. Status reports are often filed by one party, or seperately by both parties. The judge will sort it out.
